text: And Abraham was an hundred years old, when his son Isaac was born unto him.
text_kjv: And Abraham was an hundred years old, when his son Isaac was born unto him.
text_niv: Abraham was a hundred years old when his son Isaac was born to him.
text_esv: Abraham was a hundred years old when his son Isaac was born to him.
text_nlt: Abraham was 100 years old when Isaac was born.
text_msg: Abraham was a hundred years old when his son Isaac was born.
text_nasb: Now Abraham was one hundred years old when his son Isaac was born to him.
context: Genesis 21:5 serves as a simple yet profound marker of time, underscoring the miraculous nature of Isaac's birth. Understanding the historical and cultural context enriches our appreciation. In ancient Near Eastern societies, including Abraham's time, age was often equated with wisdom and status. Reaching an advanced age like one hundred years was considered a blessing, signifying divine favor and survival against the odds of disease, warfare, and famine. However, advanced age also typically signaled the end of procreative capability. Childlessness in this period carried significant social stigma, especially for women, who were primarily valued for their ability to produce heirs to carry on the family name and inheritance. Abraham's long wait for an heir, amidst numerous divine promises, tested his faith and patience repeatedly. The lack of a son threatened the fulfillment of God's covenant with him, a covenant that promised countless descendants who would bless all nations. The birth of a son in old age was viewed as a powerful testament to God's intervention and an affirmation of His faithfulness. Circumcision, established in Genesis 17, was a physical sign of this covenant, marking Abraham and his male descendants as belonging to God. Therefore, Isaac's birth at this advanced age was not just a personal joy for Abraham and Sarah but also a visible sign of God's unwavering commitment to His promises, a beacon of hope for future generations. The historical record surrounding the life expectancies of that period adds depth. While lifespans as recorded in Genesis are exceptionally long compared to modern standards, they highlight the significance of achieving an advanced age and the incredible faith required to believe for a child at that time.
meaning: The theological meaning of Genesis 21:5, "And Abraham was an hundred years old, when his son Isaac was born unto him," extends far beyond a mere statement of fact. It is a powerful declaration of God's sovereignty, faithfulness, and miraculous power. The verse highlights God's ability to work beyond the limitations of human capability and natural processes. Abraham's advanced age and Sarah's barrenness presented seemingly insurmountable obstacles to conceiving a child. Yet, God's promise prevailed, demonstrating that His power transcends human limitations. Isaac's birth is a testament to God's covenant-keeping nature. He had repeatedly promised Abraham numerous descendants, and despite the long delay and apparent impossibility, God remained faithful to His word. This reinforces the concept of God as a reliable and trustworthy source of hope. Furthermore, Isaac's birth foreshadows the coming of Jesus Christ, the ultimate fulfillment of God's promise to bless all nations through Abraham's lineage. Isaac serves as a type of Christ, being the promised son, born miraculously, and offered as a sacrifice (though ultimately spared). The verse also underscores the importance of faith. Abraham's faith was tested throughout the years of waiting, yet he persevered in believing God's promise. This verse stands as an encouragement to believers to trust in God's promises, even when circumstances seem impossible. It illustrates that God's timing is perfect, and He often works in ways that defy human understanding. The miracle of Isaac's birth is not simply a historical event; it is a theological cornerstone that reveals God's character and His plan of redemption for humanity.
application: The practical application of Genesis 21:5 in modern life is multifaceted, offering encouragement and guidance in various aspects of our journey. First, the verse underscores the importance of unwavering faith in the face of seemingly impossible situations. Just as Abraham believed God's promise despite his advanced age, we too can cultivate faith that transcends our limitations. This involves trusting God's plan even when we cannot see the path ahead. It encourages us to step out in faith, pursuing God's calling even when the odds are stacked against us. Second, Genesis 21:5 highlights the value of patience and perseverance. Abraham waited many years for the fulfillment of God's promise. In our fast-paced world, patience is often a forgotten virtue. This verse reminds us that God's timing is perfect, and we should trust Him even when the wait is long and difficult. Perseverance involves staying committed to our faith and calling, even when we face challenges and setbacks. It is about learning to trust God's process and knowing that He is working all things together for our good. Third, the verse emphasizes the power of God's intervention in our lives. Isaac's birth was a miracle, a testament to God's ability to work beyond human capabilities. In our own lives, we can expect God to intervene in miraculous ways. This requires us to be open to His leading and to trust that He can do the impossible. It means praying with boldness and expectation, knowing that God is able to answer our prayers according to His will. Fourth, the story of Abraham and Isaac challenges us to examine our own beliefs about what is possible. Often, we limit God by our own preconceived notions. This verse encourages us to expand our understanding of God's power and to believe that He can do exceedingly abundantly above all that we ask or think. Finally, it calls us to celebrate the miracles in our own lives, recognizing God's hand at work. By acknowledging God's faithfulness, we strengthen our faith and encourage others to trust in Him as well.
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank You for the story of Abraham and Sarah, and for the miracle of Isaac's birth. Lord, it is so encouraging to see Your faithfulness, even when circumstances seemed impossible. Help us to cultivate the same kind of unwavering faith that Abraham possessed, a faith that trusts in Your promises even when we cannot see the path ahead. Grant us the patience to wait for Your perfect timing, knowing that You are working all things together for our good. We ask for Your intervention in our lives, that You would perform miracles beyond our comprehension. Open our eyes to see Your hand at work, and help us to celebrate Your faithfulness. We confess that sometimes we limit You with our own doubts and fears. Forgive us, Lord, and help us to expand our understanding of Your power and goodness. We dedicate our lives to You, trusting that You will fulfill Your purpose in us. In Jesus' name, we pray. Amen.

faqs.answer: Abraham's age of 100 highlights the impossibility of conceiving naturally at that stage of life, underscoring the miraculous nature of Isaac's birth and God's intervention. It showcases God's power over natural limitations.
faqs.question: Q1: Why is Abraham's age so significant in this verse?

faqs.answer: Genesis 21:5 is a pivotal moment in fulfilling God's covenant promise to Abraham of numerous descendants. It's a tangible sign that God is faithful to His promises, despite the long wait and seeming impossibility.
faqs.question: Q2: How does this verse relate to the broader story of Abraham's covenant with God?

faqs.answer: Isaac's birth brought immense joy and relief to Abraham and Sarah. It removed the social stigma of childlessness and validated their faith in God's promises. It represented hope and the continuation of their lineage.
